sub_title: Assistant Professor at University of Twente
summary:
I graduated cum laude in 2010 from Radboud University Nijmegen as a pedagogical/educational scientist. My master thesis concerned the prevalence of switch-costs with number operations. 
Straight after graduation I started as a junior researcher at the Behavioral Science Institute Nijmegen (BSI). Here I studied the relation between language and spatial skill development in toddlers. I collaborated closely with outstanding experts in the field of language development (prof. dr. L. Verhoeven and prof. dr E. Segers). 
To foster my ambitions as an educational scientist, I moved on after ~1,5 year and acquired a PhD position at University of Twente in the department of Instructional Technology (IST). In line with my take on educational innovation at that point, I changed my research focus to serious games/games for education. Fostered by my expertise, my position there was complemented with a position as a teacher and coordinator for a variety of psychology courses and I set up my own master course in the Psychology master program 'Learning Sciences' (i.e., Learning and Individual Differences). I completed my dissertation within four years and acquired my PhD in 2016. 

Since IST is known for it's outstanding work in the field of educational psychology I decided to stay when a post-doc position came up that fit my expertise and ambition. Hence, in January 2016 I continued as a post-doc and lecturer at IST; coordinating the NWO funded project (TW1ST education) about digital tool and e-learning design for effective education of 21st century skills in technical vocational education. Aside from design and research, my position also entailed the supervision of Phd student (i.e., E.H. Eshuis), educational activities (supervision of students, teaching and coordinating several courses in the Psychology and Learning Sciences program), board memberships (like the Examination Board and department board), and acquisition of funding.

In January 2020 I was promoted to Assistent Professor at the University of Twente and my research was awarded the Brinksma Innovation Grant. Since then, I have been involved in several projects that focus on a plethora of concepts (e.g., gamification, game-based learning, e-learning, digital home literacy, language development), I coordinate several courses (i.e., Learning and Instruction, Adaptivity in Learning and Instruction, Introduction to Psychology) and supervise students of Educational Sciences, Learning Sciences and Psychology. All I do has one thing in common: the effective and efficient use and design of learning analytics.
